Overview:
As shown in Table 1, for all datasets, our proposed DMAVFL and DMAVFL_sync consistently outperform all other approaches in achieving the lowest reconstruction errors and embedding cosine distance. This underscores the effectiveness of our techniques and the advantage of embedding distribution transfer using DAC.
For the RT_IOT2022 dataset, DMAVFL_sync achieves a reconstruction error of 1.2324 and cosine distance of 0.1025, significantly outperforming FSHA, which has a reconstruction error of 1.5150 and cosine distance of 0.4929.

We illustrate all datasets and models information used in the experiments in the following Table 10, where MLP is composed of a linear and an activation, e.g., ReLU layer, CNN layer is composed a convolution process and a linear layer, and Residual block is constructed by 3 CNN layers and a skip connection.

S6.T2.caption: Table 2. Visualization of reconstructed features on the CIFAR-10 dataset with and without the defense. Except for the original image, the right side of each image is the reconstructed image. The last column is the average reconstruction error.
references: Visualization of the reconstruction: Table 2 visualizes the reconstruction performance of the proposed DMAVFL, alongside the malicious attack baselines, AGN and FSHA, for the CIFAR-10 dataset. The results clearly demonstrate that DMAVFL produces more accurate and distinct reconstructions compared to the baselines. While AGN and FSHA yield coarser results, DMAVFL maintains high-quality reconstruction even under defensive conditions. In contrast, both FSHA and AGN struggle to reconstruct informative pixels effectively when faced with defense mechanisms.

S7.T3.caption: Table 3. Reconstruction error under various adversary’s feature portions.
S7.T3.table:
Feature portion 0% 10% 20% 50% 70%
Credit DMAVFL 0.8315 0.7839 0.7489 0.6987 0.5189
sync 0.8718 0.7537 0.7154 0.6940 0.5732
IOT DMAVFL 1.7423 1.7014 1.6939 1.6382 1.5456
sync 1.7848 1.6721 1.6103 1.6056 1.2811
references: To explore how the size of the feature set held by the adversary affects the reconstruction performance of DMAVFL and sync, we conduct experiments targeting the reconstruction of 30% of the features while varying the proportion of features held by the adversary from 0% to 70%. At 0% feature possession, the scenario reduces to split learning where no features or bottom model are held by the adversary. These experiments are performed on the Credit and RT_IOT2022 (abbreviated as IOT) datasets, with the results summarized in Table 3.

Consistent with our expectations, increasing the proportion of features held by the adversary leads to improved reconstruction accuracy. As illustrated in Table 3, the reconstruction error in the Credit dataset using DMAVFL decreases from 0.8315 to 0.5189 as the feature possession increases from 0% to 70%. This trend is observed for both datasets and methods.

S7.T4.caption: Table 4. Reconstruction error and average embeddings distance using different encoder’s model.
S7.T4.table:
Encoder Metric DMAVFL sync
MLP Recon MSE 0.2545 0.2362
Emb MSE dis 7.7767 3.9726
Emb Cos dis 0.6337 0.6081
1-Res Recon MSE 0.0561 0.0434
Emb MSE dis 0.3175 0.3059
Emb Cos dis 0.1632 0.1450
3-Res (Same) Recon MSE 0.0295 0.0305
Emb MSE dis 0.4347 0.4727
Emb Cos dis 0.1006 0.1121
5-Res Recon MSE 0.0313 0.0366
Emb MSE dis 0.8771 0.7071
Emb Cos dis 0.1081 0.1112
references:
Table 4 clearly illustrates that the adversary achieves the lowest reconstruction error and the smallest embedding cosine distance when using an encoder the same as the target model, as observed for both DMAVFL and sync.
This optimal alignment underscores the importance of model congruence in enhancing the effectiveness of embedding distribution transfer and data reconstruction.
Conversely, when the encoder structure deviates from that of the target model, specifically when switching from a CNN to an MLP, the reconstruction performance significantly deteriorates, with reconstruction error increasing by an order of magnitude (from 0.0295 to 0.2545).
This dramatic drop highlights the challenges of using less compatible models for data reconstruction attack.
Moreover, the results indicate that a complex encoder, featuring a higher number of residual blocks, outperforms a simpler encoder configuration. The complex encoder not only enhances the decoder’s ability to reconstruct the data accurately but also learns a more informative embedding. This suggests that increasing the encoder’s complexity, when the target model is unknown, can lead to better performance in both embedding distribution transfer and data reconstruction.

S7.T5.caption: Table 5. Reconstruction error for different |Da​u​x|subscript𝐷𝑎𝑢𝑥|D_{aux}| relative to |Dt​r​a​i​n|subscript𝐷𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛|D_{train}|.
S7.T5.table:
|Da​u​x|:|Dt​r​a​i​n|:subscript𝐷𝑎𝑢𝑥subscript𝐷𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛|D_{aux}|:|D_{train}| 0:10 1:20 1:10 1:5 1:2 1:1
DMAVFL 0.1076 0.0315 0.0152 0.0186 0.0188 0.0172
sync 0.2311 0.0240 0.0137 0.0166 0.0178 0.0189
references:
From Table 5 we can see that significant data leakage can occur, even in the absence of auxiliary data with the same distribution of the training set (i.e., with out-of-distribution auxiliary data). This observation is highlighted by a reconstruction error of 0.1076∼similar-to\sim0.2311, when the adversary uses FashionMNIST data to reconstruct images from MNIST.
We also observe that for both DMAVFL and sync, the reconstruction error decreases quickly as |Da​u​x|subscript𝐷𝑎𝑢𝑥|D_{aux}| becomes relatively larger. However, after the ratio of |Da​u​x|:|Dt​r​a​i​n|:subscript𝐷𝑎𝑢𝑥subscript𝐷𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑖𝑛|D_{aux}|:|D_{train}| reaches 1:10, increasing auxiliary dataset size results in minor improvements in reconstruction error. This suggests that there is a threshold beyond which additional auxiliary data does not substantially improve the model’s ability to reconstruct target features, pointing to a diminishing return on the utility of expanding the auxiliary set.

S7.T6.caption: Table 6. Reconstruction errors for different numbers of target clients.
S7.T6.table:
# of target clients 1 2 3 4 5
DMAVFL 1.2789 1.5801 1.5986 1.6718 1.9820
sync 1.2324 1.6447 1.7597 1.8660 2.2635
references: The results presented in Table 6 indicate that an increase in the number of target clients, each sharing a smaller portion of the features, leads to diminished reconstruction performance. Specifically, the reconstruction error increases from 1.2789 with a single target client to 1.9828 when there are five target clients. This degradation in performance can be attributed to the distribution of features among more clients, each employing a separate bottom model to learn their respective features. This setup tends to cause the loss of crucial feature correlation information during the learning process. Moreover, as the encoder is trained on the complete set of features and is hence able to capture more feature correlations, the increased disparity between the encoder and the target models’ understanding of the feature correlation further exacerbates the challenge of accurate data reconstruction.

S8.T7.caption: Table 7. Reconstruction error against Nopeek.
S8.T7.table:
α𝛼\alpha 0 0.2 0.4 0.6 0.8 0.9 0.95 1.0
DMAVFL 0.0152 0.0151 0.0122 0.0138 0.0116 0.0171 0.0280 0.4759
sync 0.0137 0.0143 0.0122 0.0113 0.0135 0.0156 0.0403 0.4462
Honest Acc(%) 99.11 97.82 98.28 98.04 97.90 95.03 94.72 69.03
references:
We challenge Nopeek by deploying DMAVFL and sync against it with varying α𝛼\alpha values from 0.1 to 1.0 on the MNIST dataset. The results in Table 7 show that
when α<0.9𝛼0.9\alpha<0.9, Nopeek fails to thwart our attacks.
As α𝛼\alpha approaches 0.9 and beyond, Nopeek begins to impede the attack effectiveness. Notably, even at α=0.95𝛼0.95\alpha=0.95, DMAVFL still achieves a small reconstruction error of 0.0280. Setting α=1.0𝛼1.0\alpha=1.0 effectively defends the attack. However, this completely replaces the original VFL task with minimizing the D​C​O​R𝐷𝐶𝑂𝑅DCOR loss, which results in an accuracy of merely 69.03%.

S8.T8.caption: Table 8. Reconstruction error against obfuscation.
S8.T8.table:
σ𝜎\sigma 0 0.1 0.3 0.5 0.7
DMAVFL 0.0152 0.0214 0.0252 0.0351 0.0472
sync 0.0137 0.0161 0.0301 0.0497 0.0752
Honest Acc(%) 99.11 98.34 97.65 94.84 94.00
references: Obfuscation with random noise. Perturbation methods, such as adding noise to transmitted embeddings, are commonly employed in ML to safeguard privacy. Following the approach outlined in (He et al., 2020), we introduce noise with standard deviations σ𝜎\sigma ranging from 0.2 to 0.8 into the embeddings sent by target clients. This defense is tested against DMAVFL and sync on the MNIST dataset, and the results are reported in Table 8. The results suggest that higher noise levels more effectively impede the attacks. This defense is more effective for sync, as its DAC learns a dynamic distribution of the encoding embedding during training, and is more susceptible to fluctuations caused by noise. Nonetheless, our attacks manage to reconstruct informative features even under significant noise, for instance, DMAVFL achieving a reconstruction error of 0.0472 at σ=0.7𝜎0.7\sigma=0.7. It is also important to note that adding larger noise adversely affects the honest training accuracy.

S8.T9.caption: Table 9. Reconstruction error against DP. ϵ=+∞italic-ϵ\epsilon=+\infty corresponds to the scenario without DP.
S8.T9.table:
ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon 0.1 0.5 1 2 5 10 +∞\infty
DMAVFL 0.3134 0.0773 0.0443 0.0210 0.0210 0.0122 0.0152
sync 0.3178 0.1253 0.0507 0.0468 0.0172 0.0110 0.0137
Honest Acc(%) 87.75 90.00 94.97 95.90 96.72 97.36 99.11
references:
Differential privacy (DP). DP provides a mathematical framework for quantifying privacy guarantees for ML models. In our attacks, as the gradients returned from the active client may be maliciously generated, we propose to apply ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-DP mechanism, which involves adding Laplacian noise to received gradients, to disrupt the malicious training.
We test varying levels of privacy by adjusting the parameter ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon from 0.1 to 10, where a smaller ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon implies stronger privacy due to higher noise levels. The average reconstruction errors of DMAVFL and sync on MNIST are shown in Table 9, indicating that DP is most effective at an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon of 0.1, successfully impeding our proposed attacks. However, as ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon increases, its defensive effectiveness decreases. At ϵ=10italic-ϵ10\epsilon=10, the noise assists the attack, potentially by making the model updates more robust, thereby facilitating the embedding distribution transfer. It’s important to note that while DP helps to protect privacy, it also hurts the accuracy of honest training.
